video.episode_long_description: Historian Timothy Snyder discusses insights into the political climate that gave rise to Nazi Germany and resulted in the Holocaust. Then, people spend most of their lives at work so what does it mean for them when they're experiencing a mental health episode?
video.episode_short_description: New insights into the Holocaust and a look at how Ontario employers deal with mental health.
video.long_description: One in five Canadians experiences a mental health episode in their lifetime so dealing with mental health issues in the workplace is a serious concern for the economy, worker productivity, and employees themselves, who spend the majority of their time there. The Agenda looks at workplace approaches to mental health and how employers can create a mental health-positive work environment.
video.short_description: The Agenda discusses issues of mental health in the workplace.
video.title: Employee Mental Health

video.episode_long_description: As the deadline approaches for the federal government to create new legislation on physician-assisted death, The Agenda examines the issues around this important topic. Then, Matthew Fisher, Canada's longest serving foreign correspondent, highlights concerns facing the world in 2016.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda discusses physician-assisted death. Then, global issues to watch in 2016.
video.long_description: In what has become an annual tradition, Matthew Fisher, international affairs columnist for Postmedia and Canada's longest serving foreign correspondent, joins The Agenda to look ahead at the big issues facing the world in 2016.
video.short_description: Canada's longest serving foreign correspondent joins The Agenda to highlight important issues facing the world in 2016.
video.alpha_title: Matthew Fisher: World Issues to Watch in 2016
video.title: Matthew Fisher: World Issues to Watch in 2016

video.episode_long_description: As the deadline approaches for the federal government to create new legislation on physician-assisted death, The Agenda examines the issues around this important topic. Then, Matthew Fisher, Canada's longest serving foreign correspondent, highlights concerns facing the world in 2016.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda discusses physician-assisted death. Then, global issues to watch in 2016.
video.long_description: The federal government is set to craft new physician-assisted death legislation. But in the wake of last year's Supreme Court of Canada's decision striking down the law prohibiting assisted suicide, little progress has been made. The Agenda delves into this controversial topic.
video.short_description: The Agenda examines the issue of physician-assisted death.
video.keywords: Physician-assisted death|Maureen Taylor|Supreme Court of Canada
video.title: Waiting for Death

video.episode_long_description: The Agenda's food panelists, chef Jamie Kennedy of Jamie Kennedy Kitchens and food activist Joshna Maharaj, join The Agenda to discuss the long hours, high-volume workload, low pay and the personal price it takes to work in a restaurant kitchen.
video.episode_short_description: Long hours, low pay and high personal cost. The Agenda looks it what it takes to work in a restaurant kitchen.
video.long_description: In a food-obsessed world where the service, fare and ambiance of a restaurant are analyzed in detail, what goes on behind closed kitchen doors often remains a mystery. The Agenda's food panelists, chef Jamie Kennedy of Jamie Kennedy Kitchens and food activist Joshna Maharaj, discuss the long hours, low wages and the toll it takes to work in a kitchen.
video.short_description: Jamie Kennedy and Joshna Maharaj join The Agenda to discuss the high cost of working in a restaurant kitchen.
video.title: The Restaurant Environment

video.episode_long_description: The Agenda features a story making headlines this week. Then, the toll of high-cost health care, how John Sewell helped change Toronto, explaining negative interest rates, inside the mind of a con artist, how to value works of art and Emma Donoghue's Oscar nod, The Agenda reviews its week in programming.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda highlights an important story from the past week and a look back at the week of programming.
video.long_description: This past week saw 90 journalists laid off at Postmedia. The lay-offs are the latest in a long trend of shrinking newsrooms and a weakening fourth estate. The Agenda examines the state of journalism and what can be done to fix it.
video.short_description: As newsrooms continue to shrink, The Agenda considers the state of journalism and what can be done to fix it.
video.title: Shrinking Newsrooms
video.episode_title: The Agenda's Story, The Agenda's Week

video.episode_long_description: The Agenda features a story making headlines this week. Then, the toll of high-cost health care, how John Sewell helped change Toronto, explaining negative interest rates, inside the mind of a con artist, how to value works of art and Emma Donoghue's Oscar nod, The Agenda reviews its week in programming.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda highlights an important story from the past week and a look back at the week of programming.
video.long_description: Planning problems in Southern Ontario, Canada's climate change promises, delving into the mind of a con artist, and the value of art. The Agenda highlights its week of programming.
video.short_description: From a look at Ontario's planning problems to a peek inside the mind of a con artist, The Agenda highlights its week of programming.
video.keywords: The Confidence Game|Con artist|Urban planning|Greater Golden Horseshoe|Neptis Foundation|Climate change
video.title: The Agenda's Week in Review
video.episode_title: The Agenda's Story, The Agenda's Week

video.episode_long_description: The Agenda's food panelists, chef Jamie Kennedy of Jamie Kennedy Kitchens and food activist Joshna Maharaj, join The Agenda to discuss the long hours, high-volume workload, low pay and the personal price it takes to work in a restaurant kitchen.
video.episode_short_description: Long hours, low pay and high personal cost. The Agenda looks it what it takes to work in a restaurant kitchen.
video.long_description: A Pew study last year found that 88 per cent of scientists believe genetically modified foods are safe, but only 37 per cent of the public agrees. Anti-GMO activist Steven Druker says the scientists are wrong, and the authorities have intentionally misled and deceived the public when they approved GMOs for sale. The Agenda discusses his allegations and the ongoing GMO debate.
video.short_description: The Agenda examines the on-going GMO debate.
video.title: Judging GMOs

video.episode_long_description: Ottawa's National Gallery director, Marc Mayer, discusses the nature and value of art; Carl Safina tells The Agenda how dogs became "best friends" and Emma Donoghue celebrates her Oscar nod for the screenplay adaptation of her novel, "Room."
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda discusses the value of art, the nature of dogs and Oscar nominated "Room."
video.long_description: Carl Safina, author of "Beyond Words: What Animals Think and Feel," explains how one of the world's toughest mammals evolved to become humans' closest friend.
video.short_description: Carl Safina explains how dogs became the "best friend" that many think they are.
video.alpha_title: Carl Safina: Wolves, Dogs and Us
video.title: Carl Safina: Wolves, Dogs and Us

video.episode_long_description: Ottawa's National Gallery director, Marc Mayer, discusses the nature and value of art; Carl Safina tells The Agenda how dogs became "best friends" and Emma Donoghue celebrates her Oscar nod for the screenplay adaptation of her novel, "Room."
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda discusses the value of art, the nature of dogs and Oscar nominated "Room."
video.long_description: Academy Award nominations are out, and among them is some Ontario pride. London-based author Emma Donoghue is up for her screenplay adaptation of "Room," her best-selling, award-winning book about a boy and his mother hidden away from the outside world. The Agenda visits with her to discuss what it's like in Oscar's limelight, and the process of writing for the silver screen.
video.short_description: Author Emma Donoghue discusses adapting her award-winning novel, "Room," into an Oscar-nominated screenplay.
video.alpha_title: Emma Donoghue: Room at the Oscars
video.title: Emma Donoghue: Room at the Oscars

video.episode_long_description: Ottawa's National Gallery director, Marc Mayer, discusses the nature and value of art; Carl Safina tells The Agenda how dogs became "best friends" and Emma Donoghue celebrates her Oscar nod for the screenplay adaptation of her novel, "Room."
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda discusses the value of art, the nature of dogs and Oscar nominated "Room."
video.long_description: Marc Mayer, director of the National Gallery in Ottawa, explains the legacy of the gallery's 1990 purchase of Barnett Newman's "Voice of Fire." The $1.8 million price tag on the work - which one MP said could be replicated in 10 minutes with , two cans of paint and a couple of rollers, - caused a heated debate, and a lasting wariness about the worth of abstract art.
video.short_description: Ottawa's National Gallery director, Mark Mayer, discusses the nature and value of art.
video.title: Art: Edgy or Familiar

video.episode_long_description: High-care, high-cost health care users in Ontario and what can be done to ease the system's burden; a psychology writer profiles con artists and their marks and what it's like to be a permanent refugee.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda discusses high-care health care users, how a con artist's mind works and what it's like to be a permanent refugee.
video.long_description: Walter Wodchis, a University of Toronto health economist, conducted a three-year study of health care users and found that five per cent of Ontarians account for 65 per cent of health care spending. Even more surprising: one per cent of Ontarians account for a third of health care costs. Wodchis joins The Agenda to discuss his findings and recommend solutions.
video.short_description: A recent study found small percentage of Ontarians are more frequent health care users. What can be done about high-cost, high-care patiends.
video.title: High-Care High-Cost Patients

video.episode_long_description: High-care, high-cost health care users in Ontario and what can be done to ease the system's burden; a psychology writer profiles con artists and their marks and what it's like to be a permanent refugee.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda discusses high-care health care users, how a con artist's mind works and what it's like to be a permanent refugee.
video.long_description: Psychology writer Maria Konnikova talks about her book, "The Confidence Game," and the ways people can be drawn into a con. From magicians and psychics to pyramid schemes, Konnikova outlines what is going on in the brains of both the con artist and the mark.
video.short_description: Psychology writer Maria Konnikova tells Steve Paikin what goes on in the mind of a con artist.
video.title: Understanding the Con

video.episode_long_description: High-care, high-cost health care users in Ontario and what can be done to ease the system's burden; a psychology writer profiles con artists and their marks and what it's like to be a permanent refugee.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda discusses high-care health care users, how a con artist's mind works and what it's like to be a permanent refugee.
video.long_description: For all the world's attention focused on Syria's refugees, they are only the most recent group so afflicted. In 1992, Somalis fled into the United Nations High Commission on Refugees camp in Dadaab, Kenya - now home to roughly 500,000 people. Ben Rawlence, author of "City of Thorns, Nine Lives in the World's Largest Refugee Camp," joins The Agenda to discuss his look at what it's like to be a permanently displaced person.
video.short_description: Author Ben Rawlence discusses Dadaab, Kenya - a permanent refugee camp to 500,000 Somalis.
video.alpha_title: Ben Rawlence: The World's Largest Refugee Camp
video.title: Ben Rawlence: The World's Largest Refugee Camp

video.episode_long_description: The Agenda discusses how to turn climate change promises into realities and the evangelical Christian moral ground for climate change. Then, economist Jim Stanford explains negative interest rates and John Sewell remembers 1960s Toronto reform.
video.episode_short_description: Climate change, the economy and Toronto's political history are discussed on this episode of The Agenda.
video.long_description: In 1969, a slate of progressive, reform-minded councillors in Ontario's capital city set out to change the way Toronto worked. Almost a decade before he became mayor, John Sewell was one of them. He talks to Steve Paikin about what fuelled his book, "How We Changed Toronto."
video.short_description: Former Toronto mayor John Sewell reminisces about his part in reforming Toronto in the late 1960s.
video.keywords: John Sewell|Toronto mayor|Toronto City Hall|Toronto city council
video.title: Bringing Change to City Hall

video.episode_long_description: The Agenda discusses how to turn climate change promises into realities and the evangelical Christian moral ground for climate change. Then, economist Jim Stanford explains negative interest rates and John Sewell remembers 1960s Toronto reform.
video.episode_short_description: Climate change, the economy and Toronto's political history are discussed on this episode of The Agenda.
video.long_description: Economist Jim Stanford explains what negative interest rates are and why the Bank of Canada would consider taking extreme measures to drop the interest rate below zero.
video.short_description: Economist Jim Stanford explains how negative interest rates work.
video.alpha_title: Jim Stanford: Negative Interest Rate Explainer
video.title: Jim Stanford: Negative Interest Rate Explainer

video.episode_long_description: The Agenda's food panelists, chef Jamie Kennedy of Jamie Kennedy Kitchens and food activist Joshna Maharaj, join The Agenda to discuss the long hours, high-volume workload, low pay and the personal price it takes to work in a restaurant kitchen.
video.episode_short_description: Long hours, low pay and high personal cost. The Agenda looks it what it takes to work in a restaurant kitchen.
video.long_description: Katharine Hayhoe, director of the Climate Science Center at Texas Tech University, joins The Agenda to discuss her efforts to put climate change front and centre in the Republican presidential candidate race.
video.short_description: The Agenda looks at how one climate scientist is fighting to make climate change a priority in the Republican presidential candidate race.
video.alpha_title: Katharine Hayhoe: A Climate for Political Change
video.title: Katharine Hayhoe: A Climate for Political Change

video.episode_long_description: The Agenda discusses how to turn climate change promises into realities and the evangelical Christian moral ground for climate change. Then, economist Jim Stanford explains negative interest rates and John Sewell remembers 1960s Toronto reform.
video.episode_short_description: Climate change, the economy and Toronto's political history are discussed on this episode of The Agenda.
video.long_description: In December 2015 during the UN climate change summit, Paris also hosted a conference titled Christian Response to Climate Change. Katharine Hayhoe, director of the Climate Science Center at Texas Tech University, spoke at the gathering of evangelical Christians. She tells Steve Paikin about her work to bring a moral argument about climate change into the U.S. presidential race.
video.short_description: Putting Faith in Climate Science
video.title: Putting Faith in Climate Science

video.episode_long_description: The Agenda discusses whether Ontario's Places to Grow plan is still viable; American political science expert Francis Fukuyama answers 10 questions about the future, and Fred Litwin journeys from left-wing activist to Conservative supporter.
video.episode_short_description: Ontario's population growth, a political scientist's view on the future and a look into one man's journey to find a political home.
video.long_description: Fred Litwin chronicles his journey from left-wing activist in Montreal to Conservative party campaigner in "Conservative Confidential: Inside the Fabulous Blue Tent." He talks to Steve Paikin about the challenge of finding a political home as a gay conservative.
video.short_description: Fred Litwin talks about moving from left-wing activism to conservative supporter.
video.title: Journey Across Ideological Landscapes
video.episode_title: Places to Grow and Political Leanings

video.episode_long_description: The Agenda discusses whether Ontario's Places to Grow plan is still viable; American political science expert Francis Fukuyama answers 10 questions about the future, and Fred Litwin journeys from left-wing activist to Conservative supporter.
video.episode_short_description: Ontario's population growth, a political scientist's view on the future and a look into one man's journey to find a political home.
video.long_description: Francis Fukuyama, one of best-known American political scientists and author of the famous 1989 essay, "The End of History," offers his thoughts about the importance of optimism and how so far the 21st century has not offered it.
video.short_description: Political scientist and author Francis Fukuyama answers pertinent questions about the world's future.
video.alpha_title: Francis Fukuyama: 10 Questions on the Future
video.title: Francis Fukuyama: 10 Questions on the Future
video.episode_title: Places to Grow and Political Leanings

video.episode_long_description: The Agenda discusses whether Ontario's Places to Grow plan is still viable; American political science expert Francis Fukuyama answers 10 questions about the future, and Fred Litwin journeys from left-wing activist to Conservative supporter.
video.episode_short_description: Ontario's population growth, a political scientist's view on the future and a look into one man's journey to find a political home.
video.long_description: Ontario's Places to Grow growth plan is under review. The plan has a major impact on where Ontarians work, where they live and how they travel between the two. Meanwhile, a report from a leading urban policy think-tank says Ontario's knowledge of population growth is out of tune with reality. The Agenda discusses whether Ontario needs to rethink its ideas about population growth.
video.short_description: The Agenda looks at whether Ontario's Places to Grow growth plan is still viable.
video.title: Ontario's Planning Problems
video.episode_title: Places to Grow and Political Leanings

video.episode_long_description: The Agenda discusses a top story making news this week. Then, from farming labour practices to chronic pain management, the battle of the sexes and rethinking medical education, The Agenda highlights its week of programming.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda highlights an important story from the past week and a look back at the week of programming.
video.long_description: Farm internships, Toronto's rising star in the world, the battle of the sexes, John Sewell's mayoral memories, chronic pain management, rethinking medical education, the emotional life of animals, and the role of zoos in the 21st century. The Agenda highlights its week of programming.
video.short_description: The Agenda highlights its week of programming.
video.keywords: zoos|chronic pain|medical school|municipal politics|pollution|battle of the sexes|demographics
video.title: The Agenda's Week in Review
video.episode_title: The Agenda's Story, The Agenda's Week

video.episode_long_description: The Agenda discusses a top story making news this week. Then, from farming labour practices to chronic pain management, the battle of the sexes and rethinking medical education, The Agenda highlights its week of programming.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda highlights an important story from the past week and a look back at the week of programming.
video.long_description: The Canadian dollar dropped below 70 cents (US)this week, bringing it to its lowest value since 2003. Economist Craig Alexander explains why it's still falling and why that's not necessarily a bad thing.
video.short_description: Economist Craig Alexander talks about the challenges and advantages of a low Canadian dollar.
video.title: The Loonie's Losses
video.episode_title: The Agenda's Story, The Agenda's Week

video.episode_long_description: The Agenda discusses how to turn climate change promises into realities and the evangelical Christian moral ground for climate change. Then, economist Jim Stanford explains negative interest rates and John Sewell remembers 1960s Toronto reform.
video.episode_short_description: Climate change, the economy and Toronto's political history are discussed on this episode of The Agenda.
video.long_description: Late last year the Paris climate conference wrapped up with hope and celebration. Now, comes the hard part: doing what was agreed to do. David Keith, professor of applied physics at Harvard University, gives The Agenda his views on engineering a more liveable future.
video.short_description: How can countries turn their COP21 promises into real-world strategies?
video.title: Climate Conundrums

video.episode_long_description: One in five Canadians suffers from chronic pain - pain that can last for months or even years. The Agenda discusses how chronic pain is understood and its impact on society.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda discusses how chronic pain is understood and its impact on society.
video.long_description: Thousands of Ontarians suffer every day from chronic pain - persistent pain that can last for months or even longer. Some take powerful drugs simply to get by. As Ontario moves to curb the use of opioids, The Agenda explores how chronic pain is understood and its impact on society.
video.short_description: The Agenda discusses how chronic pain is understood, and its impact on society.
video.title: The Problem of Chronic Pain

video.episode_long_description: One in five Canadians suffers from chronic pain - pain that can last for months or even years. The Agenda discusses how chronic pain is understood and its impact on society.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda discusses how chronic pain is understood and its impact on society.
video.long_description: Maria Franke, curator of mammals at the Toronto Zoo, joins The Agenda to discuss how zoos are playing a role in preserving endangered species.
video.short_description: The Agenda discusses how zoos are playing a role in preserving endangered species.
video.alpha_title: Maria Franke: Conservation and the Future of Zoos
video.title: Maria Franke: Conservation and the Future of Zoos

video.episode_long_description: Author Laura Kipnis discusses her new book on men, and the still-fraught relationship between the sexes; former Toronto mayor John Sewell reminisces about his time in office and the new environmental commissioner, Dianne Saxe, explains the province's polluter-pay policy.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda discusses the never-ending battle of the sexes; a former Toronto mayor's memories and how the province tackles pollution.
video.long_description: Theodore Fontaine, author of "Broken Circle: The Dark Legacy of Indian Residential Schools" and a member of the Sagkeeng Anishinaabe First Nation, shares his thoughts on Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's approach to indigenous issues, and the importance of teaching First Nations' history to new Canadians.
video.short_description: Theodore Fontaine discusses Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's approach to indigenous issues.
video.title: Mending the Broken Circle
video.episode_title: Men, Mayors and Mucking up the Air

video.episode_long_description: What people expect of their doctors and health care is evolving at a rapid pace. Two University of Toronto faculty members join The Agenda to discuss how patient expectation affects training for the next generation of doctors.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda discusses how patient expectation impacts training for the next generation of doctors.
video.long_description: Carl Safina, author of "Beyond Words: What Animals Think and Feel," joins The Agenda to discuss why he believes treating animals ethically will lead to more kindness among human beings.
video.short_description: Author Carl Safina joins The Agenda to discuss why he believes treating animals ethically will lead to more kindness among human beings.
video.alpha_title: Carl Safina: Humane Treatment of Animals
video.title: Carl Safina: Humane Treatment of Animals

video.episode_long_description: Historian Timothy Snyder discusses insights into the political climate that gave rise to Nazi Germany and resulted in the Holocaust. Then, people spend most of their lives at work so what does it mean for them when they're experiencing a mental health episode?
video.episode_short_description: New insights into the Holocaust and a look at how Ontario employers deal with mental health.
video.long_description: "Never again" is a powerful call to remember and learn the lessons of the Holocaust and its victims. But is it possible the world has misunderstood those lessons? Historian Timothy Snyder's new book "Black Earth: The Holocaust as History and Warning" offers a very different approach: that the world has missed crucial insights from the rise of Hitler and Nazi Germany.
video.short_description: Historian Timothy Snyder discusses insights the world may have missed about the rise of Hitler, Nazi Germany and the Holocaust.
video.title: Holocaust: More Than History

video.episode_long_description: Author Laura Kipnis discusses her new book on men, and the still-fraught relationship between the sexes; former Toronto mayor John Sewell reminisces about his time in office and the new environmental commissioner, Dianne Saxe, explains the province's polluter-pay policy.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda discusses the never-ending battle of the sexes; a former Toronto mayor's memories and how the province tackles pollution.
video.long_description: Before taking on her new job as environmental commissioner of Ontario, Dianne Saxe was an eco-lawyer with a passion for addressing difficult problems such as sorting out who should pay for the contamination cleanup. She joins The Agenda to share her strong opinions about the province's approach to polluter-pay policy.
video.short_description: Environmental Commissioner Diane Saxe discusses the merits and flaws of the province's polluter pay policy.
video.title: Ontario's Polluter-Pay Policy
video.episode_title: Men, Mayors and Mucking up the Air

video.episode_long_description: Author Laura Kipnis discusses her new book on men, and the still-fraught relationship between the sexes; former Toronto mayor John Sewell reminisces about his time in office and the new environmental commissioner, Dianne Saxe, explains the province's polluter-pay policy.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda discusses the never-ending battle of the sexes; a former Toronto mayor's memories and how the province tackles pollution.
video.long_description: Former Toronto mayor John Sewell served one tumultuous term from 1978-80. He talks to Steve Paikin about those days, documented in his new book, "How We Changed Toronto." He also shares some thoughts on the current mayor of Ontario's capital city.
video.short_description: Former Toronto mayor John Sewell talks about his days at the helm in the late 1970s.
video.title: John Sewell: A Civic Life
video.episode_title: Men, Mayors and Mucking up the Air

video.episode_long_description: The Agenda finds out why farmers concerned with sustainability are still using unpaid labour; Ontario's new environmental commissioner talks about her role and a Toronto enthusiast discusses why the world is taking notice of the city.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda explore the reasons for unpaid farm labour, Ontario's environmental commissioner talks about her role and Toronto's moving on up.
video.long_description: Many small organic Ontario farms rely heavily on volunteers and unpaid interns for their labour force. But how does that square with food movements focused on justice and sustainability? Two experts join The Agenda to weigh in.
video.short_description: What does the practice of employing unpaid interns mean for farmers concerned with issues of justice and sustainability?
video.title: The Trouble with Farm Internships
video.episode_title: Farm Internships, Ontario's Environment and Toronto's Rising

video.episode_long_description: The Agenda finds out why farmers concerned with sustainability are still using unpaid labour; Ontario's new environmental commissioner talks about her role and a Toronto enthusiast discusses why the world is taking notice of the city.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda explore the reasons for unpaid farm labour, Ontario's environmental commissioner talks about her role and Toronto's moving on up.
video.long_description: The Agenda visits with Bryan Brock to find out what's driving Toronto's rising status in the world. Brock is co-founder of 1 Love TO, a website that reflects Toronto's unique character. He's also creative arts program leader at The Remix Project, an organization that helps at-risk youth focus on skills that lead to success.
video.short_description: Toronto enthusiast and at-risk youth leader, Bryan Brock discusses the city's rising star in the world.
video.title: Toronto Cool
video.episode_title: Farm Internships, Ontario's Environment and Toronto's Rising

video.episode_long_description: What people expect of their doctors and health care is evolving at a rapid pace. Two University of Toronto faculty members join The Agenda to discuss how patient expectation affects training for the next generation of doctors.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda discusses how patient expectation impacts training for the next generation of doctors.
video.long_description: Two University of Toronto faculty members join The Agenda to discuss medical school curriculum renewal and what it will mean for patient-doctor relations.

video.episode_long_description: What people expect of their doctors and health care is evolving at a rapid pace. Two University of Toronto faculty members join The Agenda to discuss how patient expectation affects training for the next generation of doctors.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda discusses how patient expectation impacts training for the next generation of doctors.
video.long_description: Nearly 10 billion people are projected to inhabit Earth by 2060. Greg Ip, chief economics commentator at the "Wall Street Journal," joins The Agenda to discuss why changing demographics raise surprising concerns.
video.short_description: Greg Ip, chief economics commentator at "The Wall Street Journal" joins The Agenda to discuss why changing demographics are raising surprising concerns.
video.alpha_title: Greg Ip: How Demographics Rule the Global Economy
video.title: Greg Ip: How Demographics Rule the Global Economy

video.episode_short_description: The Agenda explore the reasons for unpaid farm labour, Ontario's environmental commissioner talks about her role and Toronto's moving on up.
video.long_description: Thousands of residents of Dadaab refugee camp in Kenya will likely never know a home outside its fences. How common is that experience for the world's refugees? Ben Rawlence author of "City of Thorns: Nine Lives in the World's Longest Refugee Camp," discusses being a permanent refugee.
video.short_description: Author Ben Rawlence discusses refugees who live their whole lives inside a camp.
video.title: Ben Rawlence: Permanent Refugees

video.episode_long_description: One in five Canadians suffers from chronic pain - pain that can last for months or even years. The Agenda discusses how chronic pain is understood and its impact on society.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda discusses how chronic pain is understood and its impact on society.
video.long_description: When people suffer from severe mental illness, the focus is often on improving their mental health. However, severe mental illness often comes with other physical ailments that may go undiagnosed. The Agenda explores efforts to change health outcomes for people who are mentally ill.
video.short_description: The Agenda explores efforts to change health outcomes for people with mental illness.
video.alpha_title: Dr. Sanjeev Sockalingam: Medical Psychiatry Alliance
video.title: Dr. Sanjeev Sockalingam: Medical Psychiatry Alliance

video.episode_long_description: From panda problems to the ideology of wellness, The Agenda brings you the week in review.
video.episode_short_description: From panda problems to the ideology of wellness, The Agenda brings you the week in review.
video.long_description: First came a day of executions in Saudi Arabia. In retaliation, an embassy burned in Iran. Now, diplomatic relations have fallen apart between the two countries and their allies. The Agenda's foreign affairs analyst, Janice Stein, provides context for this latest conflict and what it means for the rest of the region.
video.short_description: The Agenda analyzes the conflicts between Iran and Saudi Arabia with TVO's foreign affairs analyst, Janice Stein.
video.alpha_title: Tug of War in the Middle East
video.title: Tug of War in the Middle East

video.episode_long_description: From panda problems to the ideology of wellness, The Agenda brings you the week in review.
video.episode_short_description: From panda problems to the ideology of wellness, The Agenda brings you the week in review.
video.long_description: John McCallum on Syrian refugees settling in Canada, residential school history taught in Ontario classrooms, wellness ideology as more harm than good, an interview with Ontario's new human rights commissioner, Renu Mandhane, and Ted Koppel on a what happens if power grids fail. These are the stories making The Agenda's Week in Review.
video.short_description: The Agenda highlights its week of programming.
video.keywords: power grid|residential schools|Ontario human rights|Ted Koppel|wellness|the food chain|the next ontario
video.title: The Agenda's Week in Review

video.episode_long_description: The Agenda examines Hydro One mismanagement. Then, author Sherry Turkle explains why smartphones are damaging our face-to-face relationships.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda examines Hydro One mismanagement.
video.long_description: Once a believer and now a skeptic, Sherry Turkle sees digital technology as "implicated in an assault on empathy that touches every aspect of our lives." The author of "Reclaiming Conversation" joins The Agenda to discuss why she believes sacrificing conversation for digital connection is not worth it.
video.short_description: Sherry Turkle, author of "Reclaiming Conversation", joins The Agenda to discuss why she believes sacrificing conversation for digital connection is not worth it.
video.title: Sherry Turkle: Reclaiming Conversation

video.episode_long_description: The Agenda examines Hydro One mismanagement. Then, author Sherry Turkle explains why smartphones are damaging our face-to-face relationships.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda examines Hydro One mismanagement.
video.long_description: The auditor general says Ontarians are paying too much for electricity. The Agenda's Next Ontario panel discusses whether the Liberal government has delivered the most efficient and affordable power for the province. Panelists are the Toronto Star's Martin Regg Cohn, lawyer Lisa DeMarco and consumer expert Brady Yauch.
video.short_description: The Agenda's Next Ontario panel discusses whether the Liberal government has delivered the most efficient and affordable power for the province.
video.title: Heated Over Hydro One

video.episode_long_description: The Agenda finds out why farmers concerned with sustainability are still using unpaid labour; Ontario's new environmental commissioner talks about her role and a Toronto enthusiast discusses why the world is taking notice of the city.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda explore the reasons for unpaid farm labour, Ontario's environmental commissioner talks about her role and Toronto's moving on up.
video.long_description: Among the priorities for the province's new environmental commissioner is making her office matter for Ontarians. Dianne Saxe joins The Agenda to discuss her role, as well as her experience at the climate conference in Paris late last year.
video.short_description: Dianne Saxe, Ontario's new environmental commissioner, talks about plans for her new job.
video.title: Ontario's New Eco-champion
video.episode_title: Farm Internships, Ontario's Environment and Toronto's Rising

video.episode_long_description: Author Laura Kipnis discusses her new book on men, and the still-fraught relationship between the sexes; former Toronto mayor John Sewell reminisces about his time in office and the new environmental commissioner, Dianne Saxe, explains the province's polluter-pay policy.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda discusses the never-ending battle of the sexes; a former Toronto mayor's memories and how the province tackles pollution.
video.long_description: Despite a century of feminism, relations between men and women remain a fraught topic. Author Laura Kipnis previously wrote about women and femininity ("The Female Thing"); her latest book is the opposite: "Men: Notes from an Ongoing Investigation." She joins The Agenda to discuss her fascination with men, women and their complex associations.
video.short_description: Author Laura Kipnis discusses men, women and the ongoing battle of the sexes.
video.alpha_title: Never-ending Story of Men and Women, The
video.title: The Never-ending Story of Men and Women
video.episode_title: Men, Mayors and Mucking up the Air

video.episode_long_description: Broadcaster Ted Koppel joins The Agenda to discuss why he believes a major cyber attack on North America's power grid is not only possible, but likely. Then, Ontario's new human rights commissioner, Renu Mandhane shares her priorities for her office and the province.
video.episode_short_description: Broadcaster Ted Koppel joins The Agenda to discuss why he believes a major cyber attack on North America's power grid is not only possible, but likely.
video.long_description: Fred Litwin, author of "Conservative Confidential: Inside the Fabulous Blue Tent" discusses how life has changed for members of the LGBTQ community over the past few decades.
video.short_description: Author Fred Litwin discusses how life has changed for members of the LGBTQ community over the past few decades.
video.alpha_title: 10 Questions: Being Gay Then and Now
video.title: 10 Questions: Being Gay Then and Now

video.episode_long_description: Broadcaster Ted Koppel joins The Agenda to discuss why he believes a major cyber attack on North America's power grid is not only possible, but likely. Then, Ontario's new human rights commissioner, Renu Mandhane shares her priorities for her office and the province.
video.episode_short_description: Broadcaster Ted Koppel joins The Agenda to discuss why he believes a major cyber attack on North America's power grid is not only possible, but likely.
video.long_description: What if one day all the lights go out across much of North America? And what if the cause is a cyberattack on the power grids that support today's technology-dependent lives? Ted Koppel, broadcaster and author of the book "Lights Out," joins The Agenda to discuss why he believes this is not only possible, but probable.
video.short_description: Ted Koppel, author of the book "Lights Out" joins The Agenda to discuss why he believes a cyberattack on our power grids is not only possible, but probable.
video.title: Ted Koppel: Looming Cyber Disaster

video.episode_long_description: Broadcaster Ted Koppel joins The Agenda to discuss why he believes a major cyber attack on North America's power grid is not only possible, but likely. Then, Ontario's new human rights commissioner, Renu Mandhane shares her priorities for her office and the province.
video.episode_short_description: Broadcaster Ted Koppel joins The Agenda to discuss why he believes a major cyber attack on North America's power grid is not only possible, but likely.
video.long_description: These days, to be an economist is far from being a practitioner of the "dismal science." In fact, it has become the new "it" profession. Greg Ip, chief economics commentator with the "Wall Street Journal," joins The Agenda to explain how economics became such a sought after vocation.
video.short_description: Economics is the new "it" profession. The Agenda finds out why.
video.title: How Economics Became Sexy

video.episode_long_description: The Agenda looks at how the Toronto Zoo achieved what many zoos haven't - successfully breeding giant pandas. Then, why focusing on wellness may actually be doing harm. Finally, McGill University professor William Watson on why the economic fight should be against poverty, not capitalism.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda looks at how the Toronto Zoo achieved what many zoos haven't - successfully breeding giant pandas.
video.long_description: The Occupy Wall Street movement tried to galvanize public opinion to do something about income inequality, which many thought was seriously harming society. However, in his new book, "The Inequality Trap," William Watson argues that opponents of inequality are fighting capitalism when they should be fighting poverty.
video.short_description: Income inequality should focus on poverty rather than capitalism, according to author William Watson.
video.title: William Watson: The Inequality Trap

video.episode_long_description: The Agenda looks at how the Toronto Zoo achieved what many zoos haven't - successfully breeding giant pandas. Then, why focusing on wellness may actually be doing harm. Finally, McGill University professor William Watson on why the economic fight should be against poverty, not capitalism.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda looks at how the Toronto Zoo achieved what many zoos haven't - successfully breeding giant pandas.
video.long_description: It's long been thought that healthy eating, regular exercise and positive thinking are keys to a better life. Carl Cederstrm, author of "The Wellness Syndrome" believes that wellness has instead become a destructive ideology. The professor of organization studies at the Stockholm Business School of Stockholm University joins The Agenda to discuss his counterintuitive thinking.
video.short_description: Are ideas for wellness healthy? An expert debunks wellness ideology.
video.title: The Wellness Syndrome

video.episode_long_description: Broadcaster Ted Koppel joins The Agenda to discuss why he believes a major cyber attack on North America's power grid is not only possible, but likely. Then, Ontario's new human rights commissioner, Renu Mandhane shares her priorities for her office and the province.
video.episode_short_description: Broadcaster Ted Koppel joins The Agenda to discuss why he believes a major cyber attack on North America's power grid is not only possible, but likely.
video.long_description: Renu Mandhane, recently appointed chief commissioner for the Ontario Human Rights Commission, joins The Agenda to discuss her priorities for the agency, efforts to connect with Ontario's diverse and indigenous communities, and her bold stance against street checks in Ontario.
video.short_description: Renu Mandhane, chief commissioner for the Ontario Human Rights Commission, joins The Agenda to discuss her priorities.
video.title: Renu Mandhane: Human Rights 101

video.episode_long_description: John McCallum, the federal minister of immigration, refugees and citizenship joins The Agenda to discuss the implications of fast-tracking thousands of Syrian refugees. Then, how Ontario classrooms are dealing with the troubling history of residential schools. Finally, why food has become more than just sustenance.
video.episode_short_description: John McCallum, the federal minister of immigration, refugees and citizenship joins The Agenda to discuss the implications of fast-tracking thousands of Syrian refugees.
video.long_description: Food has become more than just sustenance. It's discussed, dissected, captured on social media. People are either amateur chefs, or foodies. It's become a big part of culture. The Agenda's food chain panel, Chef Jamie Kennedy and food activist Joshna Maharaj, discusses the latest in food news.
video.short_description: The Agenda's food chain panel discusses what's new in food news.
video.title: Linking the Food Chain

video.episode_long_description: John McCallum, the federal minister of immigration, refugees and citizenship joins The Agenda to discuss the implications of fast-tracking thousands of Syrian refugees. Then, how Ontario classrooms are dealing with the troubling history of residential schools. Finally, why food has become more than just sustenance.
video.episode_short_description: John McCallum, the federal minister of immigration, refugees and citizenship joins The Agenda to discuss the implications of fast-tracking thousands of Syrian refugees.
video.long_description: The new federal government promised to bring 25,000 Syrian refugees to Canada's much safer shores by the end of next month. The target for the end of 2016 is double that. John McCallum, minister of immigration, refugees and citizenship, joins The Agenda for an update on settlement efforts across the country.
video.short_description: An update on Syrian refugee settlement in Canada with John McCallum, minister of immigration, refugees and citizenship.
video.title: From Syria with Much Anxiety

video.episode_long_description: The Agenda looks at how the Toronto Zoo achieved what many zoos haven't - successfully breeding giant pandas. Then, why focusing on wellness may actually be doing harm. Finally, McGill University professor William Watson on why the economic fight should be against poverty, not capitalism.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda looks at how the Toronto Zoo achieved what many zoos haven't - successfully breeding giant pandas.
video.long_description: Maria Franke, curator of mammals at the Toronto Zoo, joins The Agenda to discuss the successful breeding of the giant pandas on loan to Canada from the Chinese government.
video.short_description: The Agenda discusses the Toronto Zoo's success with breeding giant pandas.
video.title: Planned Pandas

video.episode_long_description: John McCallum, the federal minister of immigration, refugees and citizenship joins The Agenda to discuss the implications of fast-tracking thousands of Syrian refugees. Then, how Ontario classrooms are dealing with the troubling history of residential schools. Finally, why food has become more than just sustenance.
video.episode_short_description: John McCallum, the federal minister of immigration, refugees and citizenship joins The Agenda to discuss the implications of fast-tracking thousands of Syrian refugees.
video.long_description: The horrors of Canada's residential school system have long been absent from Ontario classrooms. The Agenda convenes a panel to discuss efforts to bring that history to students across the province.
video.short_description: The Agenda discusses efforts to bring residential school history to Ontario's class curriculum.
video.keywords: residential schools|Ontario schools|indigenous|aboriginal|First Nation|Truth and Reconciliation
video.title: Stolen Lives

video.episode_long_description: The Agenda looks at how charities have adapted to online giving. Then, volunteering is one way to be charitable. The Agenda looks at how Canadians give of their time.
video.episode_short_description: How are charities adapting to online giving, and how are Canadians giving their time to charitable activities?
video.long_description: The Agenda looks at how charities have adapted to online giving. Then, volunteering is one way to be charitable. The Agenda looks at how Canadians give of their time.
video.short_description: How are charities adapting to online giving, and how are Canadians giving their time to charitable activities?
video.title: Modern Charitable Giving

video.episode_long_description: The Agenda looks at what some are calling the new atheism. Then, two science professors discuss the meeting and departure points of science and religion.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda considers questions of science, religion and atheism.
video.long_description: Science and religion are often viewed as two subjects completely at odds with each other. But is it possible for science not only to be compatible with religion, but actually also deepen a person's faith? Biology professor Stephen Barr and physics professor Kenneth Miller join The Agenda to discuss these ideas.
video.short_description: The Agenda talks to two science professors about how science and religion collide.
video.title: Scientists on Religion

video.episode_long_description: The Agenda looks at what some are calling the new atheism. Then, two science professors discuss the meeting and departure points of science and religion.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda considers questions of science, religion and atheism.
video.long_description: The Agenda looks at what some are calling the new atheism. Then, two science professors discuss the meeting and departure points of science and religion.
video.short_description: The Agenda considers questions of science, religion and atheism.
video.title: Evolution, Science, Religion and Atheism

video.episode_long_description: Divorce is changing for the better. Anger and acrimony can be replaced by mediation and collaboration. The Agenda looks at new approaches to an old practice.
video.episode_short_description: Divorce is changing, possibly for the better.
video.long_description: Family lawyer Barbara Gordon joins The Agenda to explain the difference between regular family law, collaborative law and why the latter might be the way of the future.
video.short_description: The Agenda looks at how collaborative divorce law might be the way of the future.
video.title: Collaborative Law 101

video.episode_long_description: Divorce is changing for the better. Anger and acrimony can be replaced by mediation and collaboration. The Agenda looks at new approaches to an old practice.
video.episode_short_description: Divorce is changing, possibly for the better.
video.long_description: Four people share their stories of marriage breakdown and how they got past the upset and acrimony to put their children first and work well as co-parents.
video.short_description: The Agenda looks at what it takes to separate and co-parent amicably.
video.title: Separating Amicably

video.episode_long_description: Divorce is changing for the better. Anger and acrimony can be replaced by mediation and collaboration. The Agenda looks at new approaches to an old practice.
video.episode_short_description: Divorce is changing, possibly for the better.
video.long_description: Jenny Friedland tells her personal story of relationship collapse and how it inspired her to become a mediator. Through mediation work, she's endeavouring to change family law.
video.short_description: A family law lawyer tells the personal story that led her to practice divorce mediation.
video.title: Mediation 101

video.episode_long_description: Different opinions and beliefs can foster creative ideas and discussions. They can also create tension, fighting, even violence. The Agenda looks at how these differences play out in science and religion.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda looks at how opposing beliefs stimulate discussions about science and religion.
video.long_description: Different opinions and beliefs can foster creative ideas and discussions. They can also create tension, fighting, even violence. The Agenda looks at how these differences play out in science and religion.
video.short_description: The Agenda looks at how opposing beliefs stimulate discussions about science and religion.
video.title: On Science and Religion

video.long_description: Soulpepper theatre company's artistic director, Albert Schultz joins The Agenda to discuss his play "Frankly Sinatra," looking at the music and times of the "Chairman of the Board."
video.short_description: Albert Schultz, Artistic Director of the Soulpepper theatre company joins The Agenda to discuss his show "Frankly Sinatra."
video.keywords: Frank Sinatra|Albert Shultz|music|big band era|soulpepper theatre company
video.title: Albert Schultz: Frank Sinatra

video.episode_long_description: December 12 marked the 100th birthday of Frank Sinatra, the legendary crooner whose voice and songs enthralled generations of music lovers. The Agenda celebrates the birth of Ol' Blue Eyes by examining his life, music and legacy.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda celebrates the 100th birthday of Frank Sinatra: his life, his songbook and entertainment legacy.
video.long_description: Frank Sinatra worked hard, lived hard and loved hard. Author James Kaplan has chronicled Sinatra's life in two definitive biographies. He joins The Agenda to discuss Sinatra's life and legacy.
video.short_description: Author James Kaplan joins The Agenda to discuss Frank Sinatra's life, the subject of his two biographies.
video.keywords: Frank Sinatra|ol' blue eyes|music|big band era
video.title: James Kaplan: Sinatra at 100

video.episode_long_description: In a world overrun by too much information, how do people stay focused and not overwhelmed? The Agenda examines the historical context of information overload and its effect today. Also, one woman's experience with using gaming to bring her back to health.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda learns how gaming can help and information can lead to overwhelm.
video.long_description: Humans created more information in the past few years than in all of human history. Overstressed, sleep-deprived, and time-starved, people are living in an age of information overload, says neuroscientist Daniel Levitin. The human brain was not designed to keep up. Levitin joins The Agenda to discuss how to battle the data deluge as laid out in his book, "The Organized Mind: Thinking Straight in the Age of Information Overload."
video.short_description: What happens when the brain overloads, a common occurence in the information age? The Agenda speaks to Daniel Levitin about how to scale back.
video.title: Information Overload

video.episode_long_description: In a world overrun by too much information, how do people stay focused and not overwhelmed? The Agenda examines the historical context of information overload and its effect today. Also, one woman's experience with using gaming to bring her back to health.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda learns how gaming can help and information can lead to overwhelm.
video.long_description: Ninety per cent of all the data in the world has been created in the past few years, and people are overloaded. But this is not a new experience, says Harvard historian Ann Blair. She joins The Agenda to discuss her book, "Too Much Information: Managing Scholarly Information Before the Modern Age."
video.short_description: Information overload is not new. Harvard historian Ann Blair puts this concept in context with history.
video.title: History of Information Overload

video.episode_long_description: As Canada turns its economic sights to the Pacific, The Agenda examines the past, present and future of that part of the world, and what it means to Pacific Rim nations, which make up 45 per cent of the world's surface. First, Simon Winchester on his book exploring the Pacific Ocean, and then a discussion on the new Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda explores the Pacific with a conversation with Simon Winchester and then an examination of the details of the TPP.
video.long_description: Details of the Trans-Pacific Partnership have raised many questions. What's in the deal's fine print? Will it be ratified across the 12 member states? Can it go forward if the largest partner, the United States, doesn't pass it in Congress? Will Canada's new Liberal government seek to change the terms? The Agenda convenes a panel to discuss the meaning and impact of the long-awaited trade partnership.
video.short_description: The Agenda discusses the intricacies of the Trans-Pacific Partnership, now awaiting ratification.
video.title: Trans-Pacific and Canada's Trade Future

video.episode_long_description: As Canada turns its economic sights to the Pacific, The Agenda examines the past, present and future of that part of the world, and what it means to Pacific Rim nations, which make up 45 per cent of the world's surface. First, Simon Winchester on his book exploring the Pacific Ocean, and then a discussion on the new Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda explores the Pacific with a conversation with Simon Winchester and then an examination of the details of the TPP.
video.long_description: Author Simon Winchester takes on the world's largest ocean as the subject of his new book, "Pacific: Silicon Chips and Surfboards, Coral Reefs and Atom Bombs, Brutal Dictators, Fading Empires, and the Coming Collision of the World's Superpowers." He joins The Agenda to discuss his research and ideas.
video.short_description: Simon Winchester discusses his new book on the history, science and politics of the Pacific Ocean.
video.title: Simon Winchester: The Vast Pacific

video.episode_long_description: While history is shaped by events, it is individuals - for better or worse - who drive those events. The Agenda looks at humanity's complex relationship with the past, and how the famous and not-so famous have shaped history to form the present and the future.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda discusses how history - and its people - have shaped today and will influence tomorrow.
video.long_description: It's been more than 20 years since genocide left Rwanda in ruins. Since then, the country has been painstakingly rebuilding itself. Author Will Ferguson joins The Agenda to discuss his latest book "Road Trip Rwanda" within which he chronicles just how far the country has come.
video.short_description: Canadian novelist and travel writer Will Ferguson discusses his experiences in and impressions of Rwanda.
video.title: Will Ferguson: Rwanda Reborn

video.episode_long_description: It's no secret the relationship parents have with their offspring plays a big role in shaping the children. For better and for worse, parents help form kids into the people they become. But what happens when the apple falls far from the tree? The Agenda puts the parent/child relationship under the microscope.
video.episode_short_description: How do parents shape their children's lives? The Agenda examines the parent/child relationship.
video.long_description: Kevin Newman has had an impressive career in broadcast journalism. But as he was busy building his career, he and his son Alex grew apart. When Alex disclosed that he was gay, it forced the two men to examine their relationship. Alex and Kevin Newman join The Agenda to discuss how they confronted hard truths to strengthen their relationship.
video.short_description: Broadcaster Kevin Newman and his son reveal the struggles and ultimate strength of their relationship.
video.title: Going All Out

video.episode_long_description: It's no secret the relationship parents have with their offspring plays a big role in shaping the children. For better and for worse, parents help form kids into the people they become. But what happens when the apple falls far from the tree? The Agenda puts the parent/child relationship under the microscope.
video.episode_short_description: How do parents shape their children's lives? The Agenda examines the parent/child relationship.
video.long_description: It's no secret the relationship parents have with their offspring plays a big role in shaping the children. For better and for worse, parents help form kids into the people they become. But what happens when the apple falls far from the tree? The Agenda puts the parent/child relationship under the microscope.
video.short_description: How do parents shape their children's lives? The Agenda examines the parent/child relationship.
video.title: Family Ties

video.episode_long_description: The Agenda highlights two stories about people who pushed forward when they had every reason to fail. First, David McCallum wrongfully spent 29 years in prison. He talks about why he never gave up hope. Then, as part of The Agenda's look back at 10 seasons of programming, a conversation with Marilyn Churley. The former Ontario cabinet minister details her search for a son she gave up for adoption when she was 19.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda looks at how a wrongfully dismissed citizen reclaims his life. Then, one woman's search for the child she gave up.
video.long_description: The Agenda highlights two stories about people who pushed forward when they had every reason to fail. First, David McCallum wrongfully spent 29 years in prison. He talks about why he never gave up hope. Then, as part of The Agenda's look back at 10 seasons of programming, a conversation with Marilyn Churley. The former Ontario cabinet minister details her search for a son she gave up for adoption when she was 19.
video.short_description: The Agenda looks at how a wrongfully dismissed citizen reclaims his life. Then, one woman's search for the child she gave up.
video.title: In the Face of Adversity

video.episode_long_description: The Agenda highlights two stories about people who pushed forward when they had every reason to fail. First, David McCallum wrongfully spent 29 years in prison. He talks about why he never gave up hope. Then, as part of The Agenda's look back at 10 seasons of programming, a conversation with Marilyn Churley. The former Ontario cabinet minister details her search for a son she gave up for adoption when she was 19.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda looks at how a wrongfully dismissed citizen reclaims his life. Then, one woman's search for the child she gave up.
video.long_description: After spending 29 years in prison, wrongfully accused David McCallum has now been free for over a year. The Agenda checks in with him to discuss how he has begun to reclaim his life since his release.
video.short_description: Free after 29 years, David McCallum discusses how life has changed since his conviction was overturned.
video.alpha_title: David McCallum: A Year Out of Prison
video.title: David McCallum: A Year Out of Prison

video.episode_long_description: The Agenda discusses Ontario's growing number of "hidden patients-" those who by providing care to ill family or friends end up neglecting their own health. Then, is there a proper way to address mental illness? The Agenda discusses how language can empower or stigmatize.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda explores issues of Canada's growing caregiving community. Then, how language can empower or stigmatize those dealing with mental illness.
video.long_description: When patients are released from hospital much of their after-care is provided informally by family and friends. These caregivers are often not trained for the complexity of conditions they're tending to. They can become isolated, burdened, emotionally and physically stressed under the long hours and hard work. Caregivers are subsequently prone to ignore their own symptoms and may end up becoming ill themselves. The Agenda convenes a panel of health care practitioners and caregivers to discuss what life is like for the "hidden patient."
video.short_description: Those giving care to ill family and friends often become ill themselves. The Agenda looks at Ontario's growing number of "hidden patients."
video.title: The Hidden Patient

video.episode_long_description: The Agenda discusses Ontario's growing number of "hidden patients-" those who by providing care to ill family or friends end up neglecting their own health. Then, is there a proper way to address mental illness? The Agenda discusses how language can empower or stigmatize.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda explores issues of Canada's growing caregiving community. Then, how language can empower or stigmatize those dealing with mental illness.
video.long_description: The Agenda discusses Ontario's growing number of "hidden patients-" those who by providing care to ill family or friends end up neglecting their own health. Then, is there a proper way to address mental illness? The Agenda discusses how language can empower or stigmatize.
video.short_description: The Agenda explores issues of Canada's growing caregiving community. Then, how language can empower or stigmatize those dealing with mental illness.
video.title: Taking Good Care

video.episode_long_description: As part of The Agenda's continuing look back at ten seasons of programming, the show opens the vault on two stories about autism and one concerning cancer to highlight people who are not only rising to a challenge, but going above and beyond to inspire and encourage others who suffer similarly.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda opens the vault on its ten seasons with three stories of people rising above hardship.
video.long_description: As part of The Agenda's continuing look back at ten seasons of programming, the show opens the vault on two stories about autism and one concerning cancer to highlight people who are not only rising to a challenge, but going above and beyond to inspire and encourage others who suffer similarly.
video.short_description: The Agenda opens the vault on its ten seasons with three stories of people rising above hardship.
video.title: Going Above and Beyond

video.episode_long_description: Often another parent is the purveyor of the most critical commentary on the way one handles their children. But they can also be a great comfort to one another. The Agenda looks at how parent interaction can influence child-rearing styles and also how "lactivism -" the pressure to breast feed - is bearing down on new mothers.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda discusses how one set of parents can influence another set's parenting style. Then, how breast-feeding "lactivists" apply pressure to new mothers.
video.long_description: It's become a truism that breast is best. But author Courtney Jung argues it's gone beyond a good means of feeding infants and into the realm of a moral crusade that poses real social and political questions. The Agenda takes a closer look at breastfeeding, the mother of all motherhood issues.
video.short_description: Is breastfeeding the best option for newborns? "Lactivists" think so. The Agends discusses how new mothers are sometimes pressured to breastfeed.
video.title: Challenging Lactivism

video.episode_long_description: December 12 marked the 100th birthday of Frank Sinatra, the legendary crooner whose voice and songs enthralled generations of music lovers. The Agenda celebrates the birth of Ol' Blue Eyes by examining his life, music and legacy.
video.episode_short_description: The Agenda celebrates the 100th birthday of Frank Sinatra: his life, his songbook and entertainment legacy.
video.long_description: One of Frank Sinatra's first hits, "I'll Never Smile Again," was written by a Toronto-based musician named Ruth Lowe. The hit kickstarted a decades-long friendship. Her son, Tom Sandler, joins The Agenda to discuss their unique relationship.
video.short_description: Toronto-based musician Ruth Lowe wrote one of Frank Sinatra's first big hits. Her son, Tom Sandler, joins The Agenda to discuss the music duo.
video.title: Tom Sandler: Songwriting for Sinatra

video.episode_long_description: The Agenda looks at how sleep impacts the body and mind, the effects of lack of sufficient sleep, and the history of one of the most natural, needed and coveted pastimes.
video.episode_short_description: The Agends discusses sleep: its restorative aspects, what happens in the body and brain at rest and the history of the much needed and sometime elusive activity.
video.long_description: Sleep may feel like the most natural of human activities but historian Roger Ekirch says the way humans sleep is quite different from the way their ancestors lay their heads down to rest. The Agenda explores the idea that segmented sleep is the more advantageous way to restore the body and mind.
video.short_description: Historian Roger Ekrich talks about the characteristics of sleep through the ages.
video.title: The History of Sleep

video.episode_long_description: The Agenda looks at how sleep impacts the body and mind, the effects of lack of sufficient sleep, and the history of one of the most natural, needed and coveted pastimes.
video.episode_short_description: The Agends discusses sleep: its restorative aspects, what happens in the body and brain at rest and the history of the much needed and sometime elusive activity.
video.long_description: Birds do it. Worms do it. Animals and people do it. Sleep comprises a sizable chunk of a life. University of Toronto's Richard Horner joins The Agenda to discuss the science of sleep - why it's needed, its restorative quality, what happens in the brain during this mysterious and inaccessible period of slumber and the risks of doing without enough of it.
video.short_description: University of Toronto's Richard Horner, a professor of medicine and physiology, discusses the science of sleep.
video.title: The Science of Sleep

video.episode_long_description: Over the past several months, the news has been full of countless stories of refugees who have made dangerous journeys to try for a better life. The Agenda discusses what it takes for someone to leave their world behind, and what it takes for a new country to truly feel like home.
video.episode_short_description: What does it take to leave home to try to create a life in a new country? The Agenda looks at the refugee journey.
video.long_description: Over the past several months, the news has been full of countless stories of refugees who have made dangerous journeys to try for a better life. The Agenda discusses what it takes for someone to leave their world behind, and what it takes for a new country to truly feel like home.
video.short_description: What does it take to leave home to try to create a life in a new country? The Agenda looks at the refugee journey.
video.title: Capturing Home

video.episode_long_description: Over the past several months, the news has been full of countless stories of refugees who have made dangerous journeys to try for a better life. The Agenda discusses what it takes for someone to leave their world behind, and what it takes for a new country to truly feel like home.
video.episode_short_description: What does it take to leave home to try to create a life in a new country? The Agenda looks at the refugee journey.
video.long_description: In "The Book of Negroes," Lawrence Hill chose the topic of slavery, taking readers from West Africa, to the U.S. and Nova Scotia. In his new book, he writes stories of migrants and refugees. He joins The Agenda to discuss "The Illegal."
video.short_description: Lawrence Hill discusses his book "The Illegal," on the topic of migrants and refugees.
video.title: Lawrence Hill: Regarding Refugees

video.episode_long_description: The less certainty there is about the future, the more anxious people become about how to be prepared for it. The Agenda is joined by authors of two new books that offer glimpses of what life might look like, and what skills will be needed.
video.episode_short_description: Two authors of books about the future discuss what life might be like, and how to prepare.
video.long_description: Hal Niedzviecki's "Trees on Mars" is a travelogue across America in which the author encounters people with very different ways of trying to shape the future, have an impact on it, be aligned with what comes, or be prepared for the worst of it. What they're sacrificing is experiencing the present. What price do people pay for being too preoccupied with the future?
video.short_description: What price do people pay for being too preoccupied with the future?
video.title: Hal Niedzviecki: Trees on Mars
